 ISLAMIC FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF THE COMOROS EMERGENCY ECONOMIC RECOVERY CREDIT A. Background 1. The Islamic Federal Republic of Comoros comprises three islands in the Indian Ocean (Grande Comore, Anjouan, and Moheli), with a population of around 530,000. A fourth island, Mayotte, remained under French administration when the Islamic Federal Republic of the Comoros became independent. GNP per capita is estimated at US$356 in 2000, down from about US$500 per capita a decade ago. Comorians living in France amount to more than two-thirds of the population of the Republic. They are a source of considerable income transfers. 2. Since independence, Comoros' politics have been characterized by a high degree of political instability including numerous coups d'etat and a period of mercenary supported Governments. Even at the time of the referendum for independence ii! December 1974, the country was divided when Grande Comore, Anjouan, and Moheli voted 96 percent for independence while Mayotte voted 63 percent against. The first three islands formed the Islamic Federal Republic of the Comoros and declared their independence unilaterally on July 6, 1975, while Mayotte remained under French rule. 3. Poor economic performance and continuing poverty through the 1980's were thre consequences of the unstable political environment and weak governance. The tirst major attempt at reform was the implementation of the first adjustment program in 1991, which despite initial delays, led to improvements in public sector manag' ment. This contributed to a rise in GDP growth of 1.9 percent per annum. The 1994 devaluatior' of the Comorian Franc by 33 percent in foreign currency terms also improveu tht .ullntry's competitiveness. 4. However, weak fiscal performance and stemmed progress towrels recove.! derailed the IMF program. By way of perspective, the Bank's strategy .ti the time envisaged the potential for a 6 percent real growth rate based on consolidating the benefits of devaluation in export agriculture, deregulation, and public sectot ?ffc3 incv. Continued political turmoil and economic management problems delayed preparations for a second IDA Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC) and an IMF ;ai Mon;tored Program (SMP) through 1997 when the political crisis in Anjouan erupted. 5. The Anjouanese crisis erupted when the island attempted to secede `-frrm the Republic in 1997 due to dissatisfaction with an unresponsive central Governm' nt and declining living standards. Anjouan contains 45 percent of the country's populatioi. I .1 Anjouanese secession attempt led to the imposition of an Organization of African Unity (OAU) sponsored embargo which severely disrupted trade and exacerbated povertv. A Government invasion in 1997 was repulsed but left a legacy of armed militias in Anjouan which are a source of local instability. B. Recent Political Developments 6. Comoros' political instability results from the twin crises of separatism on Anjouan and lack of democratic legitimacy of the central Government. Anjouan
 separatists had refused to accept a compromise agreement negotiated in Antananarivo on a new union and dissatisfaction arising from the deteriorating economic situation led to unrest in Grande Comore. Riots prompted the army to intervene and take over power in a bloodless coup on March 30, 1999. 7. Efforts continued to resolve the secessionist crisis and improve the economic situation. In December 1999, a civilian Government was named under the leadership of Prime Minister Hamada Madi (Bolero), with the support of 22 out of Comoros' 30 political parties, and promised to carry out elections once the crisis is resolved. An agreement on a joint declaration between the President of the Comoros and the head of the Anjouan breakaway Government was signed in August 2000. However, the OAU would not recognize the agreement as legitimate. 8. In February 2001, after a prolonged period of mediation led by the OAU and with the assistance of the Organization of the Francophonie (OIF), the representatives of the three islands reached an agreement on a national reconciliation process. The agreement, signed in Fomboni, Moheli is known as the Fomboni Accord. 9. The Fomboni Accord provides for a transition period of one year, from the time of its signature until national elections are held under a new constitution. The new constitution, which is currently being drafted, would have as a central feature regional autonomy for each of the three islands. A referendum on the new constitution would be held between July and September 2001. Upon adoption of the constitution, a Government of national unity is expected to govern, for a period of approximately six months, and to prepare the country for national elections in early 2002. 10. During the transition, the national reconciliation process is being managed by a steering committee (Comite de Suivi) consisting of the President of the Republic, two members of the Government, two representatives of Grand Comore and Moheli, one Anjouanese official and the opposition from the three islands. The international community is represented on the Steering Committee by the OAU and OIF. The technical dimensions of the transition process are being managed by a Tri-partite Commission consisting of 72 members representing the Government, the opposition, and civil society of all three islands. The tasks of the Tri-partite Commission include the drafting of the new constitution and the design and implementation of a new financial framework. 11. The process of reconciliation is still fragile. In late April 2001, the negotiations stalled, when Anjouanese representatives withdrew their participation on the Comite de Suivi in order to protest OAU's decision to only suspend the embargo; the Anjouanese authorities demanded the embargo be lifted. The Anjouan authorities were also dissatisfied with the lack of promised financial transfers from the central Government. However, the various parties continue to endorse the reconciliation process. Indeed the Tri-partite Commission started its technical work on May 20, 2001. C. Recent Economic Developments and Poverty 12. Real GDP in Comoros is estimated to have declined by 1.1 percent in 2000 and inflation to have risen by levels close to 5 percent in 2000 due to higher petroleum prices. 2
 The trade account improved substantially with higher world prices for vanilla, cloves, and ylang-ylang, and remittances from abroad rose. The volume of exports continued to decline thus offsetting part of the potential benefits of the price rise. Imports rose only marginally. 13. Public sector management has been proactive during the past year because expenditures were reduced following lower than expected revenues. Accordingly, the overall fiscal deficit (excluding grants) amounted to 3.8 percent of GDP. The revenue decline was due to problems with a new computerized customs administration and tax arrears owed by the faltering petroleum company. Current expenditures declined from 13.8 percent of GDP in 1999 to 12.5 percent in 2000 due mainly to cuts in goods and services outlays (see table below). In the absence of foreign budgetary support, the resulting deficit was financed by growing external and internal arrears. Civil servants, who are owed up to 24 months of salary in total, were paid 11 months in 2000. Comoros is currently in arrears to its creditors. The country's external debt at end-2000 was estimated at US$225 million (113 percent of GDP) of which US$173 million was owed to multilateral creditors. Interest and principal arrears amounted to US$63 million, out of which US$24 million is owed to the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa (ABEDA), and US$18 million to the African Development Bank (AfDB). 15. Poverty was already pervasive before the current political crisis took hold. According to a 1995 ILO-sponsored household survey, some 47 percent of households and 55 percent of individuals lived below the poverty line. Anjouan with 45 percent of the population had 56 percent of households and 70 percent of individuals below the 3
 poverty line. Moheli with 5 percent ofSthe population had 55 percent of households and 64 percent of individuals below the poverty line. Grande Comore with 52 percent of the population had a third of the households and 41 percent of individuals defined as poor. 16. Although surveys and poverty analysis from post-1995 data are not available, the level of poverty is expected to have risen as per-capita growth has been negative (see table 1). Anjouan has been particularly affected as it was deprived of both imports and public services since the effectiveness of the embargo. The decline in economic growth has lowered real per capita income by an average of 3 percent a year since 1997, offset in part in Grande Comore by rising transfers from abroad. Education was disrupted by wage arrears and strikes. Health conditions deteriorated as required social expenditures were not made due to persistent budgetary problems. The net primary school enrollment rate is 53 percent and only about 58 percent of children under the age of one are immunized against prevalent childhood diseases. Only 25 percent of the population has access to potable water. D. Bank Response and Strategy 17. The Bank resumed disbursements to the Comoros following the clearance of debt service arrears in January 2000. At that time the portfolio consisted of five projects with US$26 million of undisbursed balances supporting social sectors, private sector development, and agricultural services. Two of these projects (Pilot Agricultural Services and Small Enterprise Development) were in the final implementation phases and were scheduled to close at end-December 2000 and end-June 2001, respectively. T'he Small Enterprise Development Project has been extended. 18. A Country Portfolio Performance Review (CPPR) was held in March 2000 to assess the appropriateness of the existing portfolio given the country's protracted political disputes and two year absence of Bank operations. Effective implementation of existing projects was regarded as crucial to reach the economic and social objectives of assisting Comoros to emerge from protracted conflict. The CPPR also led to initial discussions with the authorities on their national reconciliation and reconstruction strategies. The objectives of existing projects were found to be broadly valid but simplification of programs and arrangements was recommended. A detailed program of action for the following twelve months was agreed upon including acceleration of disbursements, restructuring of poorly performing projects, rebuilding project teams and strengthening project financial management. The decision was also taken to assign regional coordinators in the three islands for each project to reflect ongoing political concerns. 19. Recent progress on national reconciliation has created a new dynamic, which suggests a likely solution to the political crisis and provides a basis for the Bretton Woods institutions to resume their assistance to Comoros in support of economic and social recovery. The resumption of IDA disbursements has allowed projects to resume operations on all three islands. In March 2001, the IMF conducted an Article IV mission and also negotiated a SMP. A parallel World Bank mission assessed the economic and social situation and pre-appraised the proposed operations. 20. The World Bank's response to provide an emergency credit to the Comoros follows from the Interim Support Strategy (ISS) (IDA/R2000-182) discussed by the 4
 Board on November 14, 2000. The ISS responded to the volatile political situation and then unresolved conflict, which made it imprudent to develop a three-year Country Assistance Strategy. Instead, the resumption of Bank activities in Comoros is based on: (i) Government commitment to improving economic management and governance, (ii) the existence of major poverty problems coupled with inadequate social services, (iii) the support the Bank can give to national reconciliation and the avoidance of renewed conflict, and (iv) settlement of IDA arrears. 21. The ISS contains three scenarios - a low case, a base case and a high case. Under the low case, the existence of conflict would make it impossible to implement a coherent program, so Bank activities would stop. Under the base case, IDA would supervise the existing portfolio and process an infrastructure, water, and environment project. 22. At the time of Board presentation of the ISS, the Comoros was in a base case scenario. The ISS provides for moving to a high case scenario when Comoros shows tangible and decisive progress towards national reconciliation, which is considered a necessary pre-condition for emergency assistance to be effective, and substantial improvement in public sector management. Triggers in the ISS for the high case scenario comprise (i) good perfornance under base case scenario and (ii) preparation of an integrated budget with better fiscal management and equitable distribution of resources to the three islands. 23. Comoros' performance under the base case scenario has been good: the country has maintained a socioeconomic environment suitable for development, made progress in decentralizing project management to the islands, and has maintained satisfactory portfolio performance. An Institutional Development Fund (IDF) grant of US$471,620 was approved to provide technical assistance for public expenditure management and a national development strategy. In March 2001, a new credit (Credit No. 3468-COM) of US$11.4 million was approved focusing on infrastructure, water, and environment investments. The project is based on decentralized management in each of the three islands. The Comoros has also prepared a budget for the current fiscal year which integrates transfers between Grande Comore and Anjouan. With additional measures taken to improve financial management, Comoros has moved into the high case scenario. 24. Given the Comoros' progress on ISS triggers towards a high case scenario, IDA moved to pre-appraise the country's request for emergency assistance in March/April 2001. The mission held discussions with the authorities in Anjouan and Grande Comoros and met with representatives of multilateral and bilateral organizations. It confirmed the commitment and progress being made towards national reconciliation and the creation of a new decentralized state. The mission also concluded that the provision of emergency economic assistance was vital to alleviate distress, particularly in Anjouan, to support the rehabilitation of the economy and to consolidate the process of reconciliation and nation building. At the same time, the Bank approved a post-conflict grant of US$788,000 to reintegrate some 650 militias and other at-risk youth into the Anjouanese economy by providing training and employment opportunities. The grant will be administered by CARE International (see Attachment 2). 5
 E. Detailed Project Description 25. Comoros is in a transition. The country is emerging from conflict and moving towards economic and social rehabilitation, while putting in place the institutions of a new decentralized state. The proposed Emergency Economic Recovery Credit (EERC) is designed to support the transition until Comoros is prepared to devise and implement a medium term poverty reduction program with more conventional financial support. The proposed EERC falls within the high case scenario of IDA's ISS. Indeed, time is of the essence in this strategy as the transition program cannot be completed without foreign financing. 26. The proposed EERC is considered an appropriate instrument as it can be quick disbursing with no formal tranching. Its objectives are to maintain macroeconomic stability and address urgent social needs through financing of import costs associated with rebuilding the economy damaged during the emergency. The Government's objective is immediate recovery and institutional reforms needed to set the stage for a full post transition development program. Design of the Credit 27. The proposed Credit is designed to be implemented through the financing of a positive list of imports which will be disbursed periodically to replenish a foreign exchange account in the Central Bank. The foreign exchange will finance eligible private and public sector imports (detailed in the Development Credit Agreement). Government will request withdrawals through statements of expenditures. World Bank simplified procurement procedures as specified in its guidelines will be applied to public and private sector imports (see Attachment 5). IDA will conduct a prior review of import contracts over US$2 million. Expenditures for a single commodity import such as petroleum will not exceed one half of imports financed by the proposed Credit. No proceeds of the Credit will be used for food related items for direct consumption. 28. The proposed Credit will provide foreign exchange to cover the requirements for imports arising from the emergency recovery spending program. Based on retroactive financing, up to 20 percent will be released upon signing of the Credit. Expenditure Priorities 29. The local currency equivalent of the US$6 million EERC would finance emergency social and national reconciliation needs. It would cover about 50 percent of the estimated budgetary financing gap needed to finance the twelve-month transition. The remainder of the US$12.8 million program will be financed by other development partners. 30. The current budget will be revised by September 2001 in accordance with the agreements reached under the SMP in order to incorporate the additional emergency social and reconciliation expenditures financed by donors to meet transition needs. 31. The Government's program follows the priorities defined by the Comorian authorities (in collaboration with authorities of Anjouan and Moheli). The aggregate 6
 allocations for poverty reduction and decentralization have then been subdivided to finance island-specific expenditures. The representatives from the three islands arrived at the island-specific allocations by considering the size of the population, the level of poverty, and the needs for building decentralized institutions at each island.' Role of the IMF and Other Donors 32. In March 2001, the IMF conducted an Article IV mission and negotiated a SMP for a twelve-month period. The program to be monitored includes measures for strengthening central Government finances for the remainder of 2001 and for 2002. The program aims at avoiding further accumulation of domestic and external arrears while freeing resources to meet debt service obligations. Revenues are to be strengthened and tax exemptions eliminated. The IMF estimated that the budgetary financing gap to be covered in calendar 2001, including the transition costs, is US$8.3 million. The gap for the twelve-month period through June 2002, covering the whole transition, is estimated at US$12.8 million. 33. In order to assist the Comoros to capitalize on the progression towards national reconciliation and to seize this window of opportunity, a conference of the Friends of Comoros was held in Paris on July 5 at the Bank's office to confirm pledges to finance the transition. IDA will finance half of the transition costs, while other multi-laterals and bilaterals will cover the balance. The IMF has prepared an SMP and will present it to its Board in later July 2001. 34. Comoros' transition out of the present crisis is expected to last until mid-2002. The IMF SMP could then be transformed into a Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) after a new Government is in place and an Interim Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (I-PRSP) has been prepared. ' For a detailed description of emergency needs see Government's Letter of Development Policy in Attachment 1. 7
 G. Institutional Arrangements and Project Implementation 35. The Government has created a Office for the Implementation of the Emergency Funds which will oversee management of the proposed operation as well as assistance from other donors to the National Reconstruction and Reconciliation Program. The Office will be coordinated by the Director General for Planning and will have as membership representatives of the sectoral departments concerned with the use of the funds as well as representatives of the financial departments associated with the mobilization and use of the funds. A sub-committee will be responsible for the mobilization and control of the funds consisting of the Central Bank, Customs, Treasury, and Budget department of the Ministry of Finance. Another sub-committee for implementing the use of the funds will consist of representatives from the Ministries of Education, Health, Infrastructure and Energy, Agriculture, the Plan Directorate of Anjouan, and the coordinator of foreign donor aid. 36. The Office will serve as a project implementation unit and will ensure that the objectives of the emergency operation are met. It will also provide documentation (import bills) to IDA to enable disbursements of the operation to take place, and for ensuring their quality in accordance with World Bank procurement and disbursement guidelines. The Budget, Planning, and sectoral ministries will manage the use of the local currency counterpart of the foreign exchange to support the Government's program. 37. IDA has verified that the Government has adequate capacity to control and safeguard the use of credit resources and to ensure that the imports for which reimbursements will be claimed under the Credit will have been procured following the Bank guidelines. The Office and the Central Bank will keep adequate records of (i) all IDA funds disbursed under the Credit; (ii) conversion of IDA funds into local currency (FC); and (iii) expenditures of local currency in accordance with the agreed allocations for various social sectors and for the three islands as specified in Supplemental Letter No. 3 of the DCA In addition, the Office will submit summary financial statements every month and the results of an internal audit conducted quarterly. All transactions under EERC will also be audited by an external independent auditor acceptable to IDA as of October 2001, January 2002 and a final audit at the end of implementation of the Credit. 38. The island of Anjouan will follow the procedures established by the Office in implementing emergency expenditures. Representation of the departments on the Office would be through their counterpart sectoral ministries and the Secretariat of the Steering Committee for National Reconciliation. However, periodic audits, ad hoc surveys and site visits will also be at the disposal of the control structures on the island of Anjouan, to reinforce local institutions. Anjouanese local budgetary institutions have been managing their own expenditures even before the crisis, and will continue to do so. 39. Once the constitution has been adopted and the financial institutions of the decentralized regional island Government's have been established, the new Government will adopt a budget fully integrating revenues and expenditures for all three islands. As capacity to manage and verify the use of expenditures related to the EERC is critical to ensure program implementation, technical assistance will be provided by France in budgetary management and control. 8

POLITICAL DEVELOPMENTS AND NATIONAL RECONCILIATION The socio-economic difficulties afflicting the Comoros for decades were aggravated by a separatist crisis that began in 1997 when the island of Anjouan seceded from the Islamic Federal Republic of the Comoros. The crisis had many disastrous consequences in terms of political development and impact on development. The secessionist disturbances and the persistence of the crisis led the international community to take action against the authorities of the island of Anjouan, including suspension of cooperation and an economic embargo, which aggravated an already precarious situation. The embargo also had a negative impact on the other two islands in the Republic: Grande Comore and Moheli. The population finds itself without the financial resources essential for imports of goods and services and also without the financial support of Comorians living on the other islands. The people are demoralized by the trauma resulting from the violence and by the disruption of regional and international economic relations, and there has been a mass exodus of rural and urban population from the island of Anjouan to the other islands. This has affected economic activities in general and contributed to the increase in poverty and marked deterioration of social indicators. For example, rates of malnutrition (42.3% in 2000 compared with 33.8% in 1996) and infant mortality are rising steadily, while vaccination coverage continues to decline over the same period. Steps towards reconciliation In the last two years, there have been many political efforts to end the separatist crisis affecting the island of Anjouan. On 17 February 2001, under the auspices of the international community, the Government, the Anjouan authority, the opposition and civil society signed the Framework Agreement for national reconciliation. The Framework Agreement created a structure to promote the national reconciliation process; there will be regular evaluations and a timetable for operations. The national reconciliation process is spearheaded by two structures: a seven-member Monitoring Committee (with the participation of the international community) and a 72-member Tripartite Commission. The Tripartite Commission has various technical committees. It is to submit a preliminary version of the constitution of the New Comorian Grouping no later than six months after the signature of the Framework Agreement and to prepare a referendum on this constitution. When the new Constitution is approved, a transition Government will prepare the country for national elections to be held six months later. 9
 B. MACROECONOMIC MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES Economic growth has marked time over the last decade. It is below population growth, which is 2.7% a year. During this past decade, private sector investment was stagnant, reflecting a difficult economic environment. As a consequence, per capita income decreased from US$500 at the beginning of the 1990s to US$356 in 2000. The only growth has been in activities connected with trade in imported products. In 2000, growth contracted by 1% and inflation reached 4.8%, mainly because of the rise in oil prices. However, the trade balance improved considerably, because of higher world prices for the main exports (vanilla, cloves, ylang-ylang) and only marginal increases in the volume of imports. As a result of improved transfers from the Comorian community living abroad, the external deficit decreased from 11% of GDP in 1999 to 5% in 2000. Official gross reserves increased to 8 months' imports of goods and non-factor services at the end of 2000. The current Government's economic policy is designed to create a climate of confidence conducive to private investment in order to stimulate production activities. The goal is therefore to accelerate real GDP growth, to relieve poverty, to contain inflation, to maintain the parity of the fixed exchange rate and to keep a suitable level of monetary reserves. Practically speaking, the improvement in the political climate since February 2001 and the resumption of public investment activities in Anjouan, as well as the recent increase in world prices for revenue products, point to positive real GDP growth in 2001. As far as public finances are concerned, the Government has concentrated on maintaining financial equilibrium. In 2000, public revenue declined slightly but at the same time spending also decreased, so that the fiscal deficit remained almost unchanged: - 0.1% of GDP. The Government was able to pay 11 months of wages while continuing to make scheduled repayments of the public debt, for which 1.1 billion Comorian francs (equivalent to 2.5 months' wages) were paid out in 2000. The authorities have also improved tax collection, cleaned up the database of govemrnent employees and enhanced transparency in the management of the affairs of State. Another reason for the fiscal improvements is the restriction on spending financed from the State budget (11.2% of GDP in 2000 compared with 12.7% in 1999). In particular, spending on goods and services was reduced by an amount equivalent to 0.5% of GDP compared with 1999. The following table shows changes in the primary balance over the period from 1999 to the first half of 2002. After showing a small deficit in 2000 (although slightly higher than in 1999), the forecast primary balance will improve considerably in the following years. It shows a surplus in 2001. In relation to GDP, the primary deficit is 0.0% in 1999 and 1.12% in the first half of 2002. These favorable changes are attributable to fiscal revenue, which alone suffices to cover current government expenditure. Without external support, the Comorian State would be able to meet its basic operating expenses thanks to real managerial efforts. 10

However, in the absence of external financial aid, civil service arrears amount to 24 months and external arrears have accumulated. Civil service arrears remain a major obstacle to government reform and achievement of social stability. Aware that the country's sustainable economic development can be achieved only after resumption of relations with all its external creditors, the Comorian Government has begun discussions to find agreed and appropriate solutions to the external arrears problem. The improvements in public finance management have been achieved at considerable social and economic cost. Since domestic resources alone are not sufficient to maintain these efforts and stimulate economic activity, the Comoros is therefore asking through this conference for its friends to provide it with exceptional support in its efforts of national reconciliation, institution-building and poverty relief. B1. Short-Term Strategy The strategy of the Comoros during the transition period is to maintain a viable macroeconomic situation, in order to meet the most urgent social needs, and to ensure that the reconciliation process remains on track. Despite the signature of the Framework Agreement, the political situation remains very fragile. There is also a social crisis resulting from the accumulation of civil service 11
 wage arrears, which must be resolved; payment of two months' wages owed from 2000 could make a real contribution to the settlement of this crisis. Support for the reconciliation process has two aspects: support for decentralized institutional structures and financing of transition costs. As regards decentralization, the priorities are construction and upgrading of administrative buildings in the various islands and human resource development. With this aim, the Transition Government has embarked on the formulation of a strategy designed to stimulate the economy and to promote rehabilitation and reconstruction in the social sectors. This strategy is combined with an Emergency Reconstruction and National Reconciliation Program, drawn up after sectoral and regional technical consultations. B2. Financing of the Strategy The Comoros will appeal to all its development partners, multilateral and bilateral, for support for the national reconciliation process. The Meeting of Friends of the Comoros to be held in Paris will enable us to evaluate the strength of our partners' commitment. Total financing for the 12 months of transition amounts to US$12.8 million, including US$800,000 already obtained for the social and professional re-absorption of young militia members in Anjouan. In addition, requirements for a complete transition include financing of the cost of the elections, which will be approximately US$1.9 million. These Funds to support national reconciliation could be used to bolster the Comorian authorities' efforts to meet short-term needs, while laying the foundations for widespread recovery and a reconstruction program for the post-transition period. They would also be distributed in the light of the islands' urgent needs, bearing in mind their respective size. This is illustrated in the following matrix. Two main areas were considered important: poverty relief, on the one hand, and decentralization and national reconciliation, on the other. Poverty affects a large part of the population (47% of households), and it has therefore been decided to allocate to poverty relief 25% of the- funds to be provided directly by the partners. In view of the crucial importance of the principle of power-sharing mentioned in the Framework Agreement for national reconciliation, a large share of the total funds should be allocated to forceful action to promote decentralization and national reconciliation. 12
 The technical discussions identified the subsectors most affected by poverty in which urgent and rapid action was proposed: health, water and fisheries. The expenditure for national reconciliation covers the activities of the Monitoring Committee and the Tripartite Commission and monitoring of spending under the Credit and spending on technical coordination; the latter activities are the responsibility of the General Planning Office. C. URGENT NEEDS VOICED BY THE POPULATION Consultations involving the various technical sectors, civil society and the island authorities have identified the needs of the population. The allocation of funds for national reconciliation support reflects both the size of the population and the level of poverty in each island. In view of the scope of the Program and the resources currently available, funds will be allocated only to the priority areas indicated below. Poverty was already widespread before the outbreak of the political crisis, with almost 47% of households living below the poverty line in 1995, according to surveys conducted by the General Planning Office. The level of poverty varies from island to island: about 41% for Grande Comore, 62% for Anjouan and 52% for Moheli. Although there are no recent statistics on poverty, negative per capita growth during the crisis and the international embargo against Anjouan (since January 2000) undoubtedly had an adverse effect on the living conditions of households and the well-being of the three islands. Malnutrition reportedly reached 42% in 2000, compared with 34% in 1996 (Source: MICS 2000, Statistical Departmnent). Health services are inadequate to meet demand. The lack of infrastructures, their poor quality and the limited access to medicines, particularly for the rural population, are some of the obstacles to the delivery of satisfactory medical services. C1. Poverty Reduction, Economic Recovery and Financial Stabilization 1. Poverty Reduction An adjustment was made on the basis of the criteria of population size and incidence of poverty, giving the following distribution for the (Poverty reduction)) segment Anjouan - 50%, Moheli - 10%, Grande Comore - 40%. The consumer budget survey conducted in 1995 showed that rural inhabitants are primarily concerned by this phenomenon. Accordingly, the Government's emergency program specifies that a large share of the financing will be allocated to activities designed to improve the living conditions of these inhabitants. The activities concern access to health care and water and development of income-producing activities. This segment devoted to poverty reduction will thus finance the most urgent social and economic needs for the three islands. About 62%, or over half the population, has inadequate access to health care. Problems of availability of medicines and inadequacy of health centers (distance) are 13
 particularly widespread in rural areas. In addition, the population has insufficient access to drinking water. The total amount proposed is US$1.25 million. b) Education sector It is essential, particularly in the island of Anjouan, to repair damaged schools, develop human resources and provide textbooks and teaching materials for schools. Primary schools will be the main beneficiaries of these measures. The financing requested amounts to US$0.75 million. c) Water and environmental sanitation Almost 75% of the population has no access to drinking water, and this causes serious health problems such as diarrheal diseases. Rapid action must be taken to solve these problems. It is planned to create and extend water supply systems, particularly in rural areas. The total amount proposed is US$0.61 million. d) Rural development The great majority of Comorians live off farming and fishing. However, the system for marketing the products and the methodology are still rudimentary. This precarious situation causes loss of human life (shipwrecks) and spoilage of the catch. The Government plans to purchase fish conservation and concentration equipment, lifeboats and communications equipment. This will reduce fishing-related risks and accidents. The financing for this purpose amounts to US$0.39 million. 2. Economic Recovery and Financial Stabilization a) Domestic arrears The Government would like to repay US$2.9 million in arrears in 2001 and the first half of 2002. Considerably more arrears are owed by the Government. (i) Wages Civil servants have lost all confidence in the Government because they are owed wages amounting to almost 12 billion Comorian francs (equivalent to 24 months of wage arrears). Some 7,200 civil servants on the three islands support almost 10% of the population. These arrears problems have discouraged and demotivated civil servants, jeopardizing the functioning of the Government. In order to restore the confidence of these workers (who are essential for the good governance of the administration) and to restore the State's authority in the administration, it is essential for the Government to be able to pay at least two months' wages, including one month before the start of the school year in October 2001. Two months' wages amount to 750 million Comorian francs (equivalent to US$1.5 million) for Grande Comore and Moheli. (ii) Suppliers The State's domestic debt to its private suppliers amounts to almost US$9 million. The private sector, which is suffering considerably because of a very difficult economic 15
 environment, needs an influx of funds to jump start it. Before June 2002, 700 million Comorian francs, equivalent to US$1.4 million, will be paid to suppliers. The Government will thus be starting in June 2002 to pay part of its domestic debt, giving priority to suppliers which have complied with their tax obligations, if financing is available. b) Interregional transfers These will be used to finance the equivalent of 4 months' wages, particularly for Anjouan. Additional financing (equivalent to US$1 million) is envisaged in the program. c) Retrenchment The aim is to reduce the wage bill through the retirement or voluntary separation of 500 persons. This involves expenditure equivalent to 520 million Comorian francs (US$1 million). The State must repay the sum of 362 million Comorian francs (US$0.7 million) in order to improve its cash management. These advances are very useful to the State, allowing it to meet essential expenses in the event of a downturn. C2. Decentralization and National Reconciliation 1. Decentralization The << decentralization)> category requires 5.0% of the aid funds requested for the institutional requirements of each island. The Comorian State is pursuing a policy of administrative and - above all - economic decentralization; the new structures to be created should be staffed locally. Redeployment of civil servants In the context of institution-building and therefore of decentralization, it is essential to redeploy government workers and upgrade administrative buildings. Financing for staff redeployment in Anjouan amounts to US$0.30 million. 16
 Upgrading and construction The financing would be used for basic upgrading and priority equipment of administrative premises, particularly with information technology, for the three islands in the context of a decentralized Government. The cost is estimated at US$1.4 million. National Reconciliation The << national reconciliation)) category requires almost 18% of the funds requested from the international community. These funds would primarily finance the Tripartite Commission, resulting in a new integrated budgetary system and expenditure monitoring mechanism, as well as other forms of institutional support. This chapter concerns priority activities which cannot be divided among the islands and which are essential for the islands and for the Union. Monitoring Committee and Tripartite Commission The Monitoring Committee and the Tripartite Commission are the two organs established under the Fomboni Framework Agreement. The total cost of the activities of these two organs is US$0.5 million. The Government will contribute US$0.3 million to the expenses. The amount to be obtained is US$0.5 million. The financing requested is US$0.3 million. Other budgetary shortfall US$0.4 million. Post-Conflict US$0.8 million (obtained) Since 1999, the process of reconciliation of the three islands has speeded up. In February 2001, after a lengthy period of mediation by the Organization of African Unity and the International Organization for Francophonie, a peace agreement was signed in Fomboni (Moheli) by representatives of the Government and of the opposition in the three islands. The proposed plan will seize the opportunity provided by the peace process to promote stabilization of the social situation in Anjouan. Because of the lack of equipment and international aid, the target group - young members of the Anjouan militia - represents a major risk of civil disturbance. At present, this group is supervised by ex-soldiers who give them military training and organize sports activities. However, there is growing discontent among the young members of the Anjouan militia because of the lack of suitable housing and the lack of food and vocational training. This project will support CARE International for: (i) reintegration of from 600 to 650 former members of the Anjouan militia and young people at risk in the Anjouan economy; (ii) improvement and expansion of facilities for vocational training in Anjouan; and (iii) strengthening of the new Special Civilian Corps, which will organize 1,400 young volunteers into << committees for peace and development >>. Elections US$1.9 million (equivalent) obtained from the European Union. 18
 D. INSTITUTIONAL ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE USE OF EMERGENCY FUNDS The General Planning Office is responsible for project coordination and for preparation of the Emergency Program for Reconstruction and National Reconciliation. The emergency funds will cover certain segments of the program. All activities financed by the emergency funds will be supervised by a fund management organ - the Office for the Implementation of the Emergency Funds - which will be responsible for monitoring disbursements and activities, both at the national level and the island level. The General Planning Director will coordinate this Office. He will be responsible for coordinating all emergency activities and reporting to the Government and development partners. He will provide direct liaison between the Government and all donors, sign correspondence and authorize expenditure in the absence of government objection. The Office will assume all costs incurred for monitoring, follow-up and evaluation of activities. Monitoring arrangements: An Implementation Unit for the emergency activities will be created (hereinafter referred to as ( the Unit >>) coordinated by the General Planning office, with the following membership: - The Ministry of Education - The Ministry of Health - The Ministry of Infrastructure and Energy - The Ministry of Agriculture - The Ministry of National Reconciliation - The Representative of Anjouan - Donor coordination This Unit will be expanded to include the financial sectors responsible for the mobilization of funds et financial control. The Office will be composed as follows: - The Central Bank - The Customs - The Treasury - The Budget The Unit should be composed of permanent official members from the General Secretariats or General Offices. The financial oversight section of the Budget Ministry is responsible for the commitment of funds, while the "Commission de Wrification des Comptes Publics" should ensure that expenses are properly incurred. These two bodies would provide close supervision for emergency funds and guarantee correct execution of its activities. The Unit would be responsible for ensuring that the goals of the emergency aid are attained. Based on institutional networks and supported by external auditors, the Unit would ensure (i) presentation of eligible invoices and (ii) application of the expenditure matrix with tangible and measurable progress in the application of this matrix as presented in this Letter of Development Policy. A decree signed by the Ministry of Finance, Budget and Privatization will officially create this Unit. 19
 Attachment 2 Social and Professional Reinsertion of the Young Anjouanese Militias Because of the genesis of the Comorian crisis, there is a strong need to provide targeted assistance to reintegrate young militias and other at-risk youth into the Anjouanese economy. Anjouanese militias emerged from the attempt of the national Comorian army in September 1997 to bring Anjouan back under its control. At that time, Anjouanese authorities distributed arms to defend the island against an offensive by the national army. Due to political instability and a deteriorating social situation within Anjouan, the militias were involved in internal fighting in December 1998 and August 1999 with more than 100 people injured and killed. In the last year, most of the militias are grouped in a camp close to Patsi (Northeastern Anjouan). The group is under the supervision of former military personnel who are currently providing military training and organizing sports. However, the militias still present a major risk for civil disturbance in Anjouan because of social conditions in the camp and lack of a productive future for participants. The Bank has made available to the Government of Comoros a grant of its Post- Conflict Fund (PCF) of US$788,000 for two years (FY 2002-03) to finance the reintegration of young militia and other at-risk youth in the Anjouanese economy. The project will feed and house these people during the period of the project. This activity is closely linked to the proposed EERC and presents an important component of the authorities national reconciliation strategy. CARE International, which has a strong field presence in Grande Comore and Anjouan, will administer this project. The project aims at: (i) reintegrating 600 to 650 Anjouanese ex-militias and high-risk youth into the Anjouanese economy; (ii) upgrading and extending vocational training facilities in Anjouan; and (iii) strengthening the creation of an Adapted Civil Service (Service Civil Adapte, SCA) which will organize 1,400 young volunteers within "committees for peace and development". The project received broad support from all Comorian key stakeholders and donors. It will be linked to efforts by the OAU/OIF, assisted by the French Co-operation, to recuperate the arms of the militias. To facilitate professional reintegration and arms recuperation, CARE has already conducted a survey among the target group to identify social background, forrnal skills, expectations for future employment, and the number of arms in the hands of the militias. The results of this survey will be incorporated in an ongoing ILO study on the labor market for vocationally trained Anjouanese and linked, among others, to employment creating projects under the Bank's social fund. 20

 Attachment 5 Comoros EERC: Procurement and Disbursement Procedures The Credit will be disbursed against imports which conform to a positive list of ten categories as contained in the Development Credit Agreement (DCA). The disbursements of foreign exchange will be deposited in an account in the Central Bank. Government will use the local currency generated from the foreign expenditures to finance priority purposes related to poverty alleviation, economic recovery and decentralization. PROCUREMENT General The Office for the Implementation of the Emergency Funds (the Office) managing the project will be presided over by the Director General of Planning. A sub- committee consisting of representatives of the Central Bank and Ministry of Finance will collect documents showing proof of shipment and payment for imports included in the positive list. A second sub-committee representing the sectoral ministries will be part of the process. Eligible Imports a) Public Sector Modified ICB Procedures For contracts for eligible goods (excluding commonly traded commodities) above US$500,000 equivalent per contract, modified ICB procedures as per Para 2.63 and 2.64 of the Bank's Procurement Guidelines will apply. International Shopping Eligible goods procured by the public sector (excluding commonly traded commodities) may be procured under contracts awarded on the basis of International Shopping, as per Para 3.5 and 3.6 of the Bank's Procurement Guidelines, for imports less than the equivalent of US$500,000 per contract. b) Private Sector Goods imported by the private sector (excluding commonly traded commodities) estimated to cost less than US$2 million equivalent per contract may be procured in accordance with established commercial practices satisfactory to IDA. c) Eligible Commodities Imports of commonly traded commodities may be procured through organized international commodity markets or other channels of competitive procurement acceptable to IDA as per Para 2.65 of the Bank's Procurement Guidelines. 25
 Prior Review To the extent practicable, contracts for goods will be grouped in bid packages estimated to cost US$2 million equivalent or more each. With respect to each contract for goods estimated to cost the equivalent of US$2 million or more, the procedures set forth in Para 2 and 3 of Appendix I of the Bank's Procurement Guidelines will apply. All other contracts will be subject to post review. DISBURSEMENTS Documents showing the procurement and payment for goods will be accumulated by the Office. On the basis of these documents, the Office will prepare a statement of expenditures up to US$2 million per contract for submission to IDA. The documents verifying the eligibility of the imports will be held in the Central Bank and may be audited by IDA. Once disbursements in foreign exchange are made to the Central Bank, the local currency counterpart will be deposited in a Government account. This account will be used to finance the agreed priority program of expenditures and will be monitored by IDA as part of its supervision of the Credit. Retroactive financing, not exceeding 20% of the amount of the Credit (SDR 960,000) will be accepted for payments made for imports after April 15, 2001, i.e. approximately four months prior to the signing of the Credit. Imports under a single category may not exceed one half of the Credit amount without prior approval by IDA. 26

doc.repnme: Comoros - Emergency Economic Recovery Credit Project
doc.abstracts: The Emergency Economic Recovery Credit Project will provide emergency assistance to the economy, during the transition out of the current secessionist crisis, and will address immediate social needs in the Comoros, particularly on the island of Anjouan. Priority expenditures in the emergency program, will support the creation of decentralized institutions, and the implementation of the national reconciliation agreement. The project aims at maintaining macroeconomic stability, and addressing urgent social needs, by financing imports, including petroleum, agricultural equipment, construction materials, and capital goods, while, foreign exchange will be provided to finance increased import requirements arising from the spending, generated by the economic recovery program. The program will target urgent public expenditures needed to alleviate poverty, and support the process of national reconciliation. Nonetheless, risks include a) the possibility that the national reconciliation process, could stall, or be reversed, though careful monitoring of the process, and the strong support by stakeholders, development partners, and international mediators has been confirmed, and, b) the Government's weak capacity to sustain economic recovery efforts, but technical assistance provision in expenditure management will mitigate this risk.
